How does hardware work?

A hands-on electronics project demonstrating the implementation and testing of fundamental logic gates.

Overview

In this project, We built and tested 5 essential logic gates from scratch, creating functional circuits that demonstrate fundamental digital logic principles.

Logic Gates

  • AND Gate: Outputs 1 only when both inputs are 1
  • OR Gate: Outputs 1 when at least one input is 1
  • NOT Gate: Inverts the input (1 becomes 0, 0 becomes 1)
  • NAND Gate: NOT AND - outputs 0 only when both inputs are 1
  • NOR Gate: NOT OR - outputs 1 only when both inputs are 0

Tech Stack

Integrated Circuits Breadboard LEDs & Resistors Digital Multimeter

Video Explanation

Key Takeaway

Understanding logic gates is fundamental to digital electronics and computer architecture. This hands-on project helped us grasp the practical application of boolean algebra and circuit design.

Hour Of AI

An educational initiative at a local school explaining Microsoft Bug Arena and AI bug detection concepts.

Overview

Participated in an educational program introducing students to artificial intelligence and bug detection using Microsoft Bug Arena. This initiative aimed to inspire the next generation of developers and AI enthusiasts.

What We Covered

  • Introduction to AI: Basic concepts and real-world applications
  • Microsoft Bug Arena: How AI identifies and analyzes software bugs
  • Machine Learning Basics: Training models to detect patterns in code
  • Hands-on Demo: Live demonstration of AI bug detection in action
  • Q&A Session: Engaging discussion with students about AI careers

Key Highlights

AI Education Microsoft Tools Community Engagement STEM Outreach

Impact

This experience helped inspire students to explore AI and software development. It also reinforced my understanding of how AI is transforming bug detection and code quality assurance in modern software development.

Cardboard Katana

A Japanese katana replica constructed entirely from cardboard boxes. One of my most detailed creative masterpieces.

Overview

This project showcases the art of transforming simple, everyday materials into a detailed and visually stunning replica of a traditional Japanese katana. While not an electronics project, it represents my dedication to craftsmanship and creative problem-solving using unconventional materials.

Craftsmanship Details

  • Material: Carefully selected and layered cardboard boxes
  • Blade Design: Precisely curved and sharpened edges for authentic appearance
  • Handle & Guard: Detailed wrap and tsuba (hand guard) crafted with precision
  • Finishing: Hand-painted and sealed for durability and visual appeal
  • Total Length: Full-sized katana proportions

Skills Demonstrated

Craftsmanship Precision Design Problem-Solving Material Engineering Attention to Detail

The Challenge

Creating a structurally sound and visually authentic katana from cardboard required understanding of weight distribution, material strength, and traditional katana proportions. This project taught me that great design isn't limited to electronics—it's about understanding how to work with any material creatively and effectively.
